data.text:
Geography

Argentina is a country in the southern half of South America and borders the Atlantic Ocean in the south-east with a total coastline of 4,989 km. Bolivia and Paraguay lie to the north, Brazil and Uruguay to the northeast and Chile to the west. With a total area of around 2.78 million square kilometers, Argentina is the eighth largest country in the world and has a population of 46.65 million people. The north-south extension is over 3,600 km. The area is around 4 times that of Texas.

The geography is highly diverse and includes the Andes in the west, home to South America's highest mountain, Aconcagua (6,959 m), and the fertile pampas in the center of the country. The Gran Chaco and the wetlands of the Iberá run to the north, while the Patagonian Desert can be found in the south. The semi-desert of Monte on the edge of the Puna in the west is also striking.

Most important cities

Argentina's population density averages 16.8 inhabitants per square kilometer, with most people living in cities. With a strikingly high proportion of 92.3 percent, the vast majority of inhabitants belong to the urban population. The capital Buenos Aires and the cities of Córdoba and Rosario have the highest population figures. The population of the Buenos Aires metropolitan area alone is estimated to be just under 15 million, or around a third of all Argentinians.

Away from the cities, especially in the north and south of the country, the population density is considerably lower. The coastal regions and the pampas in the center of the country are the most densely populated. The country is divided into 23 provinces, each with its own government and constitution, which in turn are subdivided into departments. The exception is the city of Buenos Aires, which is considered autonomous and has a special role as the capital.

The difference between the urban area and the city proper alone can be considerable. San Juan, for example, has an urban population of 545,000. However, the actual proper city is much smaller with only 109,000 inhabitants. The difference to metropolitan regions, i.e. conurbations with several cities, is even greater.
